title: PLEASE DISABLE NEW CHAMPS IN RANKED
body: I know many of us have been asking for this for years. I am tired of losing a ban for the week after every champ release. If I don't, I know 100% that someone is going to pick the new champ, who they have MAYBE PLAYED ONCE and ruin the game, whether it be on my team or the other. They are going to go 0/7 in lane almost every time simply because they have no idea how the champ works.

Players have their own play styles, strengths, and weaknesses. I can guarantee to you that I will perform better on Jhin than I would on Tahm Kench, a champion that is a must-pick/ban in the pro scenes and a insta-ban in solo queue. I will perform better on Jhin than I would on Eve, a cancer champion for an entire year that also made appearances in the pro scenes. I would perform better on Jhin than I would on Vayne, one of the most well-known and used champion in the history of league.

Why? Because I'm typically bad at the champions I've mentioned and decent at champions like Jhin. You don't need to see a champion to understand its play style:

Passive: Cait's passive
Q: Ryze's bouncing thing with a different damage calculation
W: Lucian's Q with CC
E: Teemo's shrooms with less damage and AOE effect
R: Xerath's ult but with a straight line skill shot twist

How to play Jhin:
1. Harass with every 4th hit.
2. Use W in combo with Support Harass to proc CC
3. Place flower (e) things in gank entrances and bushes, or use to zone if pushing
4. R units out of position/too far from your position, or if you are dying and want to dish out your last remaining damages.

Of course, a new player wouldn't be completely proficient and might have to warm up, but Jhin seems like a really easy champion to play. *I've never played him before.

What's the worst that can happen? They lose a game? I don't think i'll ever encounter a person who says, "It's so hard to get the champion I want in normals - let's try it in ranked."

You should require certain mastery points to play champs in Ranked, much like Smites mastery system. it works like this (or at least it did when i played in Season 1, start of Season 2)

Gods have mastery levels going to 10. You need X amount of Gods at mastery level 1 in order to even queue for Leagues(ranked matches)..

Then, if you meet those requirements, you cannot play gods IN LEAGUES unless you have the god you're selecting at Mastery level 1. This system ensures you can play the god you're choosing (at least at a rudimentary level, the amount of games it takes for mastery level 1 in smite is enough to make you understand, Nemesis'((shes my main, hence the bias)) for example and play her on a rudimentary level. 

So not only do you require basic knowledge of X amount of gods(i think its 12 Gods needed, although it might have been 16) you also require that if you want to play certain gods(in the case of my example, new gods) you MUST practice with them in normal games and acquire God Mastery points and achieve rank 1. 


What my point is, this system could be beneficial to League, because it certainly alleviates a lot of new character lock ins and "oh X is broken I'll just choose him even though I've NEVER play him" from champ select.

I feel like new champs should be disabled in ranked for similar reasons as to why competitive matches are played without the most recent champion(s) (and indeed, often not even the most recent patches).

It's rarely a level playing field. They either have PBE experience (but teammates/opponents don't) so it can be unfair one way or another, or there might be bugs that haven't had a chance to be discovered (PBE is decent for catching things, but nothing compares to live), or they pretty much necessarily don't have the experience with the champ to use it effectively. (Yes, people are dumb and try champs for the first time in ranked even when the champ isn't new, but at least in that context they could at least have experience playing against the champ and have a sense for what can be done.)

The problem lies in the fact that people have no idea how to play when behind, which you probably will be if you play a champ for the first time in ranked, and then they tend to just feed their ass off. 

Just stay calm and farm. Did you die? Well it is a good thing Jihn is ranged so you can still farm safely-ish. Pick up kills with your range, assist with the utility you bring. Stay back and land W´s on feeling foes. Use E to protect your other carries. Use your ult when you are safe and no enemy is MIA. Don´t play him in ranked for the first time.

See? Easy things to remember.

Actually... what about this idea.

To play a Champion in Bronze, you need Mastery I.

To play a Champion in Silver, you need to be Mastery II.

To play a Champion in Gold, you need to be Mastery III.

To play a Champion in Platinum, you need a Mastery IV.

To play a Champion in Diamond, you need a Mastery V.

You can't move to the next Level without 16 Champions (the requirement for Ranked) with a proper Mastery.

Im curious, what would you say his weaknesses are for opposing champion picks, and which allied champs give him the ability to be strong?
Because I don't want to waste a ban, but I also want to be able to beat him.

He is extremely weak to hard engages, i was Morgana support with a Jhin (ranked) vs a Leona & Lucian. 
When leona went in i spelshielded her stun but after that she caught Jhin with the edge of her ult and he melted in under 1 second

He seems weak at actual tower destruction(comparitively), because you can't crit towers, he gains no attack speed outside natural growth, AND stops to reload every 4 shots. A trist can destroy a tower in seconds, it takes him quite some time compared to most adcs. 

also seems exremely vulnerable to flanking, his kit naturally focuses the player's attention forward. 

Ult, W, are his main sniping offense and are easily bodyblocked, so any half decent tank should severely reduce his kill power, forcing him to fight with his atrocious attack speed. 


Looks to have very strong laning and siege, so the real question is whether or not he's better than cait: IMO, more fun to play but not quite as good at the end of the day.
